'White people shoot at us': Southern Brazil's Indigenous communities fight for ancestral land
subhead: In Mato Grosso do Sul, a southern state bordering Paraguay, Indigenous people who tried to reclaim the lands from which they had been dispossessed face violence from large landowners. The left-wing government largely remains powerless in the face of this tragedy.
byline: By Bruno Meyerfeld (Kurusu Amba, Dourados [Brazil], special correspondent)

Journalists in the West Bank face mounting suppression
subhead: Since October 7, Israel has arrested and imprisoned at least 140 journalists working in this occupied territory, most often under the catch-all charge of 'incitement to terrorism.' The Palestinian Journalists Syndicate has condemned what it describes as a strategy to 'silence' media professionals.
byline: By Lucas Minisini (Ramallah (West Bank) special correspondent)

title: Millions return home as Pacific tsunami warnings lifted
subhead: Storm surges of up to 4 meters were predicted for some parts of the Pacific, after the 8.8 quake struck off Russia's Kamchatka peninsula. The US Geological Survey said the quake was one of the 10 strongest tremors recorded since 1900. It was followed by dozens of aftershocks that further shook the Russian Far East

title: Mount Etna: Sicily's protective, thunderous mother
subhead: 'Of Volcanoes and Men' (1/6). Volcanoes sow death when they erupt and give life through their fertile soil, inspiring fear and fascination. Between 2018 and 2023, Sicilian photographer Emanuele Occhipinti spent long months on the slopes of Mount Etna. Beyond the majestic landscapes, his images reveal the daily life of villagers living near this unpredictable 'mother,' toward whom they feel a love mixed with apprehension.

title: Gabriel Hagaï, a mystic and political rabbi
subhead: Hagaï, 57, has lived a thousand lives. A specialist in Hebrew manuscripts, the religious figure who embraces mystical Judaism has also been a baker in Boston, a researcher and, currently, a herbalist.

subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (3/6). Katja Lange-Müller, born in the German Democratic Republic (GDR), managed as an adult to cross 'to the other side' of the Wall, escaping her mother, a prominent member of the communist regime.

title: 'In the West Berlin squats, we argued but lived together': Karin Wieland, political rebel
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (2/6). In the late 1970s, Karin Wieland fled her small German town to live communally in an abandoned building in Kreuzberg, throwing herself into every cause of the era.
